multiple-choice.question: According to Mark Zuckerberg, what is a filter bubble, and how does it affect our online experience?

options.label: A
options.text: A filter bubble is a type of online community that is created by shared interests.

options.label: B
options.text: A filter bubble is a personal bubble of information that is created by algorithms, and it isolates us from other people's perspectives.

options.label: C
options.text: A filter bubble is a type of online advertising that targets specific groups.

options.label: D
options.text: A filter bubble is a type of information that is curated by human editors.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem with algorithmic filters, according to Mark Zuckerberg?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too slow and can't keep up with the amount of information online.

options.label: B
options.text: They can throw off the balance between information and entertainment, leading to an "information junk food" diet.

options.label: C
options.text: They are too expensive to maintain.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not transparent enough.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "epic struggle" that Mark Zuckerberg refers to in the context of Netflix cues?

options.label: A
options.text: The struggle between our future aspirational selves and our more impulsive present selves.

options.label: B
options.text: The struggle between our online and offline lives.

options.label: C
options.text: The struggle between our desire for information and our desire for entertainment.

options.label: D
options.text: The struggle between our need for speed and our need for accuracy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the founding mythology of the internet and the reality of how the internet works today, according to Mark Zuckerberg?

options.label: A
options.text: The internet used to be a broadcast society, but now it's a more personalized experience.

options.label: B
options.text: The internet used to be controlled by human gatekeepers, but now it's controlled by algorithms.

options.label: C
options.text: The internet used to be a slow and expensive experience, but now it's fast and affordable.

options.label: D
options.text: The internet used to be a place for entertainment only, but now it's a place for information and education.

multiple-choice.question: What is the responsibility of the new gatekeepers of the internet, according to Mark Zuckerberg?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the internet faster and more affordable.

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure that the internet is a place for entertainment and fun.

options.label: C
options.text: To encode a sense of civic responsibility and public life into the code of the algorithms.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the internet a place for only a select few.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge that Mark Zuckerberg thinks the internet faces today?

options.label: A
options.text: The challenge of keeping up with the amount of information online.

options.label: B
options.text: The challenge of ensuring that the internet is a place for all people, not just a select few.

options.label: C
options.text: The challenge of making the internet faster and more affordable.

options.label: D
options.text: The challenge of ensuring that the internet is a place for only entertainment and fun.

multiple-choice.question: According to Mark Zuckerberg, what is the importance of journalistic ethics in the context of the internet?

options.label: A
options.text: Journalistic ethics are not important in the context of the internet.

options.label: B
options.text: Journalistic ethics are only important in the context of traditional media.

options.label: C
options.text: Journalistic ethics are essential in the context of the internet to ensure that citizens have access to accurate and unbiased information.

options.label: D
options.text: Journalistic ethics are only important in the context of online advertising.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why Mark Zuckerberg thinks the internet needs to be a place for all people, not just a select few?

options.label: A
options.text: So that the internet can be a place for only entertainment and fun.

options.label: B
options.text: So that the internet can be a place for only information and education.

options.label: C
options.text: So that the internet can be a place for all people to connect and share ideas.

options.label: D
options.text: So that the internet can be a place for only a select few to control.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message that Mark Zuckerberg wants to convey to the audience at the end of his speech?

options.label: A
options.text: That the internet is only for entertainment and fun.

options.label: B
options.text: That the internet is only for information and education.

options.label: C
options.text: That the internet needs to be a place for all people, not just a select few, and that it needs to be a place for connection and sharing of ideas.

options.label: D
options.text: That the internet is only for a select few to control.

title: What we can learn from galaxies far, far away - Henry Lin

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: Why do we cry? The three types of tears - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is special about Iris's lacrimal glands?

options.label: A
options.text: They only produce basal tears.

options.label: B
options.text: They produce tears in excess, but not uniquely.

options.label: C
options.text: They are designed to make new tears and drain old ones away.

options.label: D
options.text: They don't produce tears at all.

multiple-choice.question: 2) What is the main purpose of the basal tears that Iris constantly produces?

options.label: A
options.text: To wash away harmful substances.

options.label: B
options.text: To stabilize Iris's mood.

options.label: C
options.text: To keep dirt and debris away from Iris's eyes by forming a thin coating of three layers.

options.label: D
options.text: To make Iris cry uncontrollably.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when Onion takes off her jacket, and why does Iris start crying?

options.label: A
options.text: A chemical reaction converts the sulfoxides into a substance that makes Iris happy.

options.label: B
options.text: A chemical reaction converts the sulfoxides into a substance called syn-Propanethial S-oxide, which stings Iris and causes her to cry.

options.label: D
options.text: Onion's jacket is too loose, and Iris is allergic to the fabric.

multiple-choice.question: What is different about the reflex tears that Iris produces when Onion takes off her jacket?

options.label: A
options.text: They are released in smaller amounts.

options.label: B
options.text: They contain fewer antibodies to stop microorganisms.

options.label: C
options.text: They are released in much larger amounts and contain more antibodies to stop microorganisms.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the same as basal tears.

multiple-choice.question: Why does Iris start crying again after Onion walks out the door?

options.label: A
options.text: Because she is still allergic to the substance on Onion's jacket.

options.label: B
options.text: Because she is still in love with Onion.

options.label: C
options.text: Because she is now crying emotional tears, which are sent to stabilize her mood as quickly as possible.

options.label: D
options.text: Because she is still upset about the breakup.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of emotional tears?

options.label: A
options.text: To wash away harmful substances.

options.label: B
options.text: To stabilize the mood as quickly as possible.

options.label: C
options.text: To elicit sympathy or show submission.

options.label: D
options.text: To make Iris cry uncontrollably.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the physical reactions that occur when Iris is either too sad or happy?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased heart rate and faster breathing.

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased heart rate and slower breathing.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased heart rate and slower breathing.

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased heart rate and faster breathing.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the substances found in emotional tears?

options.label: A
options.text: Only stress hormones.

options.label: B
options.text: Only endorphins.

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the story about Iris and Onion?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of having three kinds of tears.

options.label: B
options.text: The dangers of being allergic to certain substances.

options.label: C
options.text: The importance of emotional tears in stabilizing the mood.

options.label: D
options.text: The story is about Iris's love for Onion.

multiple-choice.question: What is the story tells us about Iris's tears?

options.label: A
options.text: Iris only cries emotional tears.

options.label: B
options.text: Iris's basal tears are the only kind of tears she produces.

options.label: C
options.text: Iris has all three kinds of tears, which work together to keep her balanced and healthy.

options.label: D
options.text: Iris's tears have no special properties.

multiple-choice.question: What is the aqueous layer in the basal tears responsible for?

options.label: A
options.text: To keep dirt and debris away from Iris's eyes.

options.label: B
options.text: To stabilize Iris's mood.

options.label: C
options.text: To keep Iris hydrated, repel invasive bacteria, and protect her skin from damage.

options.label: D
options.text: To make Iris cry uncontrollably.

multiple-choice.question: What is the lipid layer in the basal tears responsible for?

options.label: A
options.text: To keep dirt and debris away from Iris's eyes.

options.label: B
options.text: To stabilize Iris's mood.

options.label: C
options.text: To keep the surface smooth for Iris to see through and prevent the other layers from evaporating.

options.label: D
options.text: To make Iris cry uncontrollably.
